prob Package¶

bn Module¶

Contains¶

  • BayesianNetworkNode

class ProbPy.prob.bn.BayesianNetwork(network)[source]¶

Bases: builtins.object

Class that implements a Bayesian Network. It encapsulates some algorithms for Bayesian inference and abstract their usage

eliminationAsk(query_var, observed)[source]¶

Executes the Elimination Ask algorithm, receiving a query variable (q) and observations (E), returning a factor which corresponds to the distribution P(q | E)

Arguments: query_var – Random variable of type RandVar observed – List of observations. Each element of the list should be

a tuple, which first element is a RandVar and second element is the observed value for that variable
Example:
>>> # Assuming X, Y and Z as vars and vz, vy as values of X and Y
>>> observed = [(X, vx), (Y, vy)]
>>> res = BN.eliminationAsk(Z, observed)
>>> res # P(Z | X=vx, Y=vy)
isHidden(var, query_var, observed)[source]¶

Checks if the variable is the query variable or has any observation. If it doesn’t, then the variable is hidden

var – RandVar object with variable that is being tests if it’s
hidden or not

query_var – Query variable for the algorithm observed – Array with observations following the convention of

eliminationAsk method
makeFactor(arg_factor, observed)[source]¶

Takes a factor and instantiates what is observed

arg_factor – Factor in question observed – Array with observations following the convention of

eliminationAsk method
nodeInGraph(node)[source]¶

Look for the node, if the node was not found, return None

sumOut(var, arg_factors)[source]¶

Sums the variable in var out, meaning that this function will return the product of the factors in arg_factors and will take var out

var – RandVar object that will be summed out arg_factors – Factors which will have var summed out

topoSortNet(unsorted_net)[source]¶
exception ProbPy.prob.bn.BayesianNetworkArgEx[source]¶

Bases: builtins.Exception

Exception used if the nodes of the Bayesian Network don’t form a DAG

class ProbPy.prob.bn.BayesianNetworkNode(node, factor, parents)[source]¶

Bases: builtins.object

This class represents a node in a Bayesian Network. It has the notion of it’s variable, it’s probability distribution represented using a factor and it’s parents.

class ProbPy.prob.factor.Factor(rand_vars, values)[source]¶

Bases: builtins.object

Represents a Factor. A Factor has one or more random variables associated with an array of values. The array of values is a vectorization of the multi dimensional matrix that represents the factor.

Examples:
>>> # Assuming X and Y are variables
>>> XY_factor = Factor([X, Y], [0.2, 0.3, 0.1, 0.4])
add(factor)[source]¶

Addition operation for factorOp

div(factor)[source]¶

Division operation for factorOp

exp()[source]¶

Applies the exp function to the whole factor. Exp implemented by Python’s library

expectedValue(fun)[source]¶

Calculates the expected value for the variables in rand_vars. The method should be used if the factor represents a probability distribution. Suppose the factor f(X) would represent the distribution P(X), this method would calculate the expected value of X, E[X].

If the factor f(X, Y) represents the distribution P(X | Y), the expected value calculated is E[X]

Arguments: fun – A function for the variable

Examples:
>>> X_factor = RandVar(X, ["T", "F"])
>>> X_factor.Factor(X, [0.8, 0.2])
>>> X_ev.Factor(X, [10, 20])
>>> X_factor.expectedValue(X, X_ev)
12.0
factorOp(factor, fun)[source]¶

Function used by others to implement a factor operation between self and another factor.

Arguments: factor – The other factor used for this operation fun – Operation used between each element of the values

getValuesListSize(rand_vars)[source]¶
instVar(rand_vars, insts)[source]¶

Instantiates a random variables of a factor. Instantiating variable X with value vx and Y with vy would yield f(X=vx, Y=vy, Z) = f(Z).

Arguments: rand_vars – List of variables to instantiate insts – Value for each variable

Note, the sizes of the lists must be the same. Variable rand_vars[k] will be instantiated with value insts[k].

instVarSingle(rand_var, inst)[source]¶

Same has instVar, but this method instantiates a single variable and it is the one used in the implementation of instVar.

Arguments: rand_var – Variable to instantiate inst – Value for variable

log(base)[source]¶

Applies the logarithm function to the whole factor. The actual logarithm used in the one in Python’s library

Arguments: base – Base of the logarithm

map(fun)[source]¶

Returns the result of applying a function the factor. Useful in the implementation of the log function

Arguments: fun – Function used in the mapping

marginal(arg_rand_vars)[source]¶

Calculates the marginal of a factor for a list of random variables. For example, if XY_factor is the distribution P(X, Y). Calculating the marginal of X will give P(X).

mult(factor)[source]¶

Multiplication operation for factorOp

normalize(arg_rand_vars)[source]¶

Normalizes the factor for random variables in the distribution. If the factor of variable X has values [1, 3], the normalization will yield the [1/4, 3/4], distribution. If a factor represents the distribution P(X, Y), normalizing for X will yield P(X | Y).

pow(p)[source]¶

Calculates the power of the elements in the factor by p

Arguments: p – Values of power used

scalar(factor, scalar_value, fun)[source]¶

Scalar operation between factor and a scalar_value. The scalar is used in an operation, defined by fun, with the values of factor.

Arguments: factor – The factor which values are going to be used as

operands with scalar

scalar_value – An int or float value to serve as an operand fun – Function used in the operation, may be a lambda

sub(factor)[source]¶

Subtraction operation for factorOp

class ProbPy.prob.factor.RandVar(name, domain)[source]¶

Bases: builtins.object

Represents a Random Variable in a probability distribution. Each variable is identified by a string which is it’s name. If two RandVar in a script have the same name, the library will assume they are the same variable.

Each variable also has a domain. The domain is a list of values which the variable can take. As of this version the elements on the list should only be of the string type. In later versions other types will be allowed. Maybe even types that are other objects.

Examples:
>>> coin = RandVar("Coin", ["Head", "Tail"])
>>> ball = RandVar("Ball", ["Red", "Green", "Blue"])

Bases: builtins.Exception
